defs.docs: ureq is a minimal request library.

attributes.value: / ureq is a minimal request library.
/ The goals of this library are:
/   // sync post request of some json.
/     // This can include errors like failure to parse URL or connect timeout.
/     // They are treated as synthetic HTTP-level error statuses.
/ Most standard methods (GET, POST, PUT etc), are supported as functions from the
/ These top level http method functions create a [Request](struct.Request.html) instance
/ which follows a build pattern. The builders are finished using:
/ * [`.send()`](struct.Request.html#method.send) with a request body as `Read` (chunked encoding support for non-known sized readers).
/ By enabling the `ureq = { version = "*", features = ["json"] }` feature,
/ To maintain a state, cookies, between requests, you use an [agent](struct.Agent.html).
/ Agents also follow the build pattern. Agents are created with
/ The library will set the content length on the request when using
/ For responses, if the `Content-Length` header is present, the methods that reads the
/ body (as string, json or read trait) are all limited to the length specified in the header.
/ Dechunking is a response body is done automatically if the response headers contains
/ Sending a chunked request body is done by setting the header prior to sending a body.
/ By enabling the `ureq = { version = "*", features = ["charset"] }` feature,
/ the library supports sending/receiving other character sets than `utf-8`.
/ header `Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1` and if it contains a charset
/ specification, we try to decode the body using that encoding. In the absence of, or failing
/ to interpret the charset, we fall back on `utf-8`.
/ we first check if the user has set a `; charset=<whatwg charset>` and attempt
/ to encode the request body using that.
/ Rather than exposing a custom error type through results, this library has opted for
/ representing potential connection/TLS/etc errors as HTTP response codes. These invented codes
/ The idea is that from a library user's point of view the distinction of whether a failure
/ originated in the remote server (500, 502) etc, or some transient network failure, the code
/ path of handling that would most often be the same.
/ As a result, reading from a Response may yield an error message generated by the ureq library.
/ To handle these errors, use the

defs.name: Agent

attributes.value: / By default, no state, such as cookies, is kept between requests.
/ But by creating an agent as entry point for the request, we

 connection pooling.

defs.name: set_resolver
defs.value:
pub fn set_resolver<impl crate::Resolver + 'static: crate::Resolver +
                    'static>(&mut Self, impl crate::Resolver + 'static)
-> &mut Self
defs.docs:
Configures a custom resolver to be used by this agent. By default,
 address-resolution is done by std::net::ToSocketAddrs. This allows you
 to override that resolution with your own alternative. Useful for
 testing and special-cases like DNS-based load balancing.

attributes.value: / Configures a custom resolver to be used by this agent. By default,
/ address-resolution is done by std::net::ToSocketAddrs. This allows you
/ to override that resolution with your own alternative. Useful for
/ testing and special-cases like DNS-based load balancing.
/ A `Fn(&str) -> io::Result<Vec<SocketAddr>>` is a valid resolver,
/ passing a closure is a simple way to override. Note that you might need
/ explicit type `&str` on the closure argument for type inference to

defs.name: new
defs.value: pub fn new<S: AsRef<str>>(S) -> Result<Self, Error>
defs.docs:
Create a proxy from a format string.
 # Arguments:
 * `proxy` - a str of format `<protocol>://<user>:<password>@<host>:port` . All parts except host are optional.
 # Protocols
 * `http`: HTTP Connect
 * `socks`, `socks5`: SOCKS5 (requires socks feature)
 # Examples
 * `http://127.0.0.1:8080`
 * `socks5://john:smith@socks.google.com`
 * `john:smith@socks.google.com:8000`
 * `localhost`

attributes.value: / Create a proxy from a format string.
/ * `proxy` - a str of format `<protocol>://<user>:<password>@<host>:port` . All parts except host are optional.

defs.name: build
defs.docs:
"Builds" this request which is effectively the same as cloning.
 This is needed when we use a chain of request builders, but
 don't want to send the request at the end of the chain.

defs.name: timeout_connect
defs.value: pub fn timeout_connect(&mut Self, u64) -> &mut Request
defs.docs:
Timeout for the socket connection to be successful.
 If both this and .timeout() are both set, .timeout_connect()
 takes precedence.

attributes.value: / Timeout for the socket connection to be successful.
/ If both this and .timeout() are both set, .timeout_connect()
/ The default is `0`, which means a request can block forever.

defs.name: timeout_read
defs.value: pub fn timeout_read(&mut Self, u64) -> &mut Request
defs.docs:
Timeout for the individual reads of the socket.
 If both this and .timeout() are both set, .timeout()
 takes precedence.

attributes.value: / Timeout for the individual reads of the socket.
/ If both this and .timeout() are both set, .timeout()
/ The default is `0`, which means it can block forever.
/     .timeout_read(1_000) // wait max 1 second for the read

/ The default is `0`, which means it can block forever.

defs.name: timeout
defs.value: pub fn timeout(&mut Self, time::Duration) -> &mut Request
defs.docs:
Timeout for the overall request, including DNS resolution, connection
 time, redirects, and reading the response body. Slow DNS resolution
 may cause a request to exceed the timeout, because the DNS request
 cannot be interrupted with the available APIs.

attributes.value: / Timeout for the overall request, including DNS resolution, connection
/ time, redirects, and reading the response body. Slow DNS resolution
/ may cause a request to exceed the timeout, because the DNS request
/ cannot be interrupted with the available APIs.
/ This takes precedence over .timeout_read() and .timeout_write(), but
/ // wait max 1 second for whole request to complete.

defs.name: into_reader
defs.docs: Turn this response into a `impl Read` of the body.

attributes.value: / Turn this response into a `impl Read` of the body.
/ 1. If `Transfer-Encoding: chunked`, the returned reader will unchunk it
/ 2. If `Content-Length` is set, the returned reader is limited to this byte
/    length regardless of how many bytes the server sends.
/ 3. If no length header, the reader is until server stream end.

defs.name: into_string
defs.docs:
Turn this response into a String of the response body. By default uses `utf-8`,
 but can work with charset, see below.

attributes.value: / Turn this response into a String of the response body. By default uses `utf-8`,
/ but can work with charset, see below.
/ This is potentially memory inefficient for large bodies since the
/ implementation first reads the reader to end into a `Vec<u8>` and then
/ attempts to decode it using the charset.
/ Attempts to respect the character encoding of the `Content-Type` header and
/ I.e. `Content-Length: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1` would be decoded in latin-1.
